dn17:1.1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying between a pair of sal trees in the sal forest of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā at the time of his final extinguishment.

dn17:1.2.3: There are other great cities such as
dn17:1.2.4: Campā, Rājagaha, Sāvatthī, Sāketa, Kosambī, and Benares.
dn17:1.2.5: Let the Buddha become fully extinguished there.
dn17:1.2.6: There are many well-to-do aristocrats, brahmins, and householders there who are devoted to the Buddha. They will perform the rites of venerating the Realized One’s corpse.”

dn17:1.3.4: Once upon a time there was a king named Mahāsudassana whose dominion extended to all four sides, and who achieved stability in the country.
dn17:1.3.5: His capital was this Kusinārā, which at the time was named Kusāvatī.
dn17:1.3.6: It stretched for twelve leagues from east to west, and seven leagues from north to south.
dn17:1.3.7: The royal capital of Kusāvatī was successful, prosperous, populous, full of people, with plenty of food.
dn17:1.3.8: It was just like Āḷakamandā, the royal capital of the gods, which is successful, prosperous, populous, full of spirits, with plenty of food.
dn17:1.3.10: Kusāvatī was never free of ten sounds by day or night, namely:
dn17:1.3.11: the sound of elephants, horses, chariots, drums, clay drums, arched harps, singing, horns, gongs, and handbells; and the cry, ‘Eat, drink, be merry!’ as the tenth.
dn17:1.4.1: Kusāvatī was encircled by seven ramparts:
dn17:1.4.2: one made of gold, one made of silver, one made of beryl, one made of crystal, one made of ruby, one made of emerald, and one made of all precious things.
dn17:1.5.2: made of gold, silver, beryl, and crystal.

dn17:1.7.1: King Mahāsudassana possessed seven treasures and four blessings.
dn17:1.7.3: On a fifteenth day sabbath, King Mahāsudassana had bathed his head and gone upstairs in the royal longhouse to observe the sabbath.
dn17:1.7.4: And the heavenly wheel-treasure appeared to him, with a thousand spokes, with rim and hub, complete in every detail.
dn17:1.7.6: ‘I have heard that when the heavenly wheel-treasure appears to a king in this way, he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.
dn17:1.7.7: Am I then a wheel-turning monarch?’
dn17:1.8.1: Then King Mahāsudassana, rising from his seat and arranging his robe over one shoulder, took a ceremonial vase in his left hand and besprinkled the wheel-treasure with his right hand, saying:
dn17:1.8.2: ‘Roll forth, O wheel-treasure! Triumph, O wheel-treasure!’
dn17:1.8.3: Then the wheel-treasure rolled towards the east. And the king followed it together with his army of four divisions. In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army.
dn17:1.9.1: And any opposing rulers of the eastern quarter came to him and said,
dn17:1.9.2: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’
dn17:1.9.4: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink alcohol. Maintain the current level of taxation.’
dn17:1.9.5: And so the opposing rulers of the eastern quarter became his vassals.
dn17:1.10.1: Then the wheel-treasure, having plunged into the eastern ocean and emerged again, rolled towards the south. …
dn17:1.10.2: Having plunged into the southern ocean and emerged again, it rolled towards the west. …
dn17:1.10.3: Having plunged into the western ocean and emerged again, it rolled towards the north, followed by the king together with his army of four divisions.
dn17:1.10.4: In whatever place the wheel-treasure stood still, there the king came to stay together with his army.
dn17:1.10.5: And any opposing rulers of the northern quarter came to him and said,
dn17:1.10.6: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’
dn17:1.10.8: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink alcohol. Maintain the current level of taxation.’
dn17:1.10.9: And so the opposing rulers of the northern quarter became his vassals.
dn17:1.11.1: And then the wheel-treasure, having triumphed over this land surrounded by ocean, returned to the royal capital of Kusāvatī. There it stood still by the gate to Mahāsudassana’s royal compound at the High Court as if fixed to an axle, illuminating the royal compound.
dn17:1.11.2: Such is the wheel-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.12.1: Next, the elephant-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.12.2: It was an all-white sky-walker with psychic power, touching the ground in seven places, a king of elephants named Sabbath.
dn17:1.12.3: Seeing him, the king was impressed,
dn17:1.12.4: ‘This would truly be a fine elephant vehicle, if he would submit to taming.’
dn17:1.12.5: Then the elephant-treasure submitted to taming, as if he was a fine thoroughbred elephant that had been tamed for a long time.
dn17:1.12.6: Once it so happened that King Mahāsudassana, testing that same elephant-treasure, mounted him in the morning and traversed the land surrounded by ocean before returning to the royal capital in time for breakfast.
dn17:1.12.7: Such is the elephant-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.13.1: Next, the horse-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.13.2: It was an all-white sky-walker with psychic power, with head of black and mane like woven reeds, a royal steed named Thundercloud.
dn17:1.13.3: Seeing him, the king was impressed,
dn17:1.13.4: ‘This would truly be a fine horse vehicle, if he would submit to taming.’
dn17:1.13.5: Then the horse-treasure submitted to taming, as if he was a fine thoroughbred horse that had been tamed for a long time.
dn17:1.13.6: Once it so happened that King Mahāsudassana, testing that same horse-treasure, mounted him in the morning and traversed the land surrounded by ocean before returning to the royal capital in time for breakfast.
dn17:1.13.7: Such is the horse-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.14.1: Next, the jewel-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.14.2: It was a beryl gem that was naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked, transparent, clear, and unclouded, endowed with all good qualities.
dn17:1.14.3: And the radiance of that jewel spread all-round for a league.
dn17:1.14.4: Once it so happened that King Mahāsudassana, testing that same jewel-treasure, mobilized his army of four divisions and, with the jewel hoisted on his banner, set out in the dark of the night.
dn17:1.14.5: Then the villagers around them set off to work, thinking that it was day.
dn17:1.14.6: Such is the jewel-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.15.1: Next, the woman-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.15.2: She was attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. She was neither too tall nor too short; neither too thin nor too fat; neither too dark nor too light. She outdid human beauty without reaching divine beauty.
dn17:1.15.3: And her touch was like a tuft of cotton-wool or kapok.
dn17:1.15.4: When it was cool her limbs were warm, and when it was warm her limbs were cool.
dn17:1.15.5: The fragrance of sandal floated from her body, and lotus from her mouth.
dn17:1.15.6: She got up before the king and went to bed after him, and was obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely.
dn17:1.15.7: The woman-treasure did not betray the wheel-turning monarch even in thought, still less in deed.
dn17:1.15.8: Such is the woman-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.16.1: Next, the householder-treasure appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.16.2: The power of clairvoyance manifested in him as a result of past deeds, by which he sees hidden treasure, both owned and ownerless.
dn17:1.16.3: He approached the king and said,
dn17:1.16.4: ‘Relax, sire. I will take care of the treasury.’
dn17:1.16.5: Once it so happened that the wheel-turning monarch, testing that same householder-treasure, boarded a boat and sailed to the middle of the Ganges river. Then he said to the householder-treasure,
dn17:1.16.6: ‘Householder, I need gold coins and bullion.’
dn17:1.16.7: ‘Well then, great king, draw the boat up to one shore.’
dn17:1.16.8: ‘It’s right here, householder, that I need gold coins and bullion.’
dn17:1.16.9: Then that householder-treasure, immersing both hands in the water, pulled up a pot full of gold coin and bullion, and said to the king,
dn17:1.16.10: ‘Is this sufficient, great king? Has enough been done, great king, enough offered?’
dn17:1.16.12: ‘That is sufficient, householder. Enough has been done, enough offered.’
dn17:1.16.13: Such is the householder-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.

dn17:1.18.2: He was astute, competent, intelligent, and capable of getting the king to appoint who should be appointed, dismiss who should be dismissed, and retain who should be retained.
dn17:1.18.3: He approached the king and said,
dn17:1.18.5: Such is the counselor-treasure that appeared to King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.18.6: These are the seven treasures possessed by King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.18.9: And what are the four blessings?
dn17:1.18.10: He was attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty, more so than other people.
dn17:1.19.1: Furthermore, he was long-lived, more so than other people.
dn17:1.20.1: Furthermore, he was rarely ill or unwell, and his stomach digested well, being neither too hot nor too cold, more so than other people.

dn17:1.25.2: ‘Come, dear Vissakamma, build a palace named Principle as a home for King Mahāsudassana.’
dn17:1.25.3: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Vissakamma. Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, he vanished from the gods of the Thirty-Three and appeared in front of King Mahāsudassana.
dn17:1.25.5: ‘I shall build a palace named Principle as a home for you, sire.’

dn17:2.3.1: Then he entered the great foyer and sat on the golden couch. Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, he entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
dn17:2.3.2: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, he entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
dn17:2.3.3: And with the fading away of rapture, he entered and remained in the third absorption, where he meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
dn17:2.3.4: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, he entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

dn17:2.5.1: King Mahāsudassana had 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.

dn17:2.9.2: ‘Come, mister, bring the golden couch from the great foyer and set it up in the golden palm grove.’
dn17:2.9.3: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ that man replied, and did as he was asked.
dn17:2.9.4: The king laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.
dn17:2.10.2: ‘The king’s faculties are so very clear, and the complexion of his skin is pure and bright. Let him not pass away!’ She said to him,
dn17:2.10.3: ‘Sire, you have 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.
dn17:2.10.4: Arouse desire for these! Take an interest in life!’
dn17:2.10.5: And she likewise urged the king to live on by taking an interest in all his possessions as described above.
dn17:2.11.1: When the queen had spoken, the king said to her,
dn17:2.11.2: ‘For a long time, my queen, you have spoken to me with loving, desirable, pleasant, and agreeable words.
dn17:2.11.3: And yet in my final hour, your words are undesirable, unpleasant, and disagreeable!’
dn17:2.11.4: ‘Then how exactly, Your Majesty, am I to speak to you?’
dn17:2.11.6: “Sire, we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved. Don’t pass away with concerns. Such concern is suffering, and it’s criticized.
dn17:2.11.7: Sire, you have 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.
dn17:2.11.8: Give up desire for these! Take no interest in life!”’
dn17:2.11.9: And so on for all the king’s possessions.
dn17:2.12.1: When the king had spoken, Queen Subhaddā cried and burst out in tears.
dn17:2.12.2: Wiping away her tears, the queen said to the king:
dn17:2.12.3: ‘Sire, we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved. Don’t pass away with concerns. Such concern is suffering, and it’s criticized.
dn17:2.12.4: Sire, you have 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost.
dn17:2.12.5: Give up desire for these! Take no interest in life!’
dn17:2.12.6: And she continued, listing all the king’s possessions.
dn17:2.13.1: Not long after that, King Mahāsudassana passed away.
dn17:2.13.2: And the feeling he had close to death was like a householder or their child falling asleep after eating a delectable meal.
dn17:2.13.3: When he passed away King Mahāsudassana was reborn in a good place, a Brahmā realm.
dn17:2.13.4: Ānanda, King Mahāsudassana played children’s games for 84,000 years.
dn17:2.13.5: He ruled as viceroy for 84,000 years.
dn17:2.13.6: He ruled as king for 84,000 years.
dn17:2.13.7: He led the spiritual life as a layman in the Palace of Principle for 84,000 years.
dn17:2.13.8: And having developed the four Brahmā meditations, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a Brahmā realm.
dn17:2.14.2: ‘Surely King Mahāsudassana must have been someone else at that time?’
dn17:2.14.3: But you should not see it like that. I myself was King Mahāsudassana at that time.
dn17:2.14.4: Mine were the 84,000 cities, with the royal capital of Kusāvatī foremost. And mine were all the other possessions.
dn17:2.15.1: Of those 84,000 cities, I only stayed in one, the capital Kusāvatī.
dn17:2.15.2: Of those 84,000 mansions, I only dwelt in one, the Palace of Principle.
dn17:2.15.3: Of those 84,000 chambers, I only dwelt in the great foyer.
dn17:2.15.4: Of those 84,000 couches, I only used one, made of gold or silver or ivory or heartwood.
dn17:2.15.5: Of those 84,000 bull elephants, I only rode one, the royal bull elephant named Sabbath.
dn17:2.15.6: Of those 84,000 horses, I only rode one, the royal horse named Thundercloud.
dn17:2.15.7: Of those 84,000 chariots, I only rode one, the chariot named Triumph.
dn17:2.15.8: Of those 84,000 women, I was only served by one, a maiden of the aristocratic or merchant classes.
dn17:2.15.9: Of those 8,400,000,000 cloths, I only wore one pair, made of fine linen, cotton, silk, or wool.
dn17:2.15.10: Of those 84,000 servings of food, I only had one, eating at most a serving of rice and suitable sauce.
dn17:2.16.1: See, Ānanda! All those conditioned phenomena have passed, ceased, and perished.
dn17:2.16.5: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.
dn17:2.17.1: Six times, Ānanda, I recall having laid down my body at this place. And the seventh time was as a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king, at which time my dominion extended to all four sides, I achieved stability in the country, and I possessed the seven treasures.
dn17:2.17.2: But Ānanda, I do not see any place in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans where the Realized One would lay down his body for the eighth time.”
dn17:2.17.3: That is what the Buddha said.
dn17:2.17.4: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
dn17:2.17.6: their nature is to rise and fall;
